articles.summary: Libertyville Montessori School in Libertyville, Illinois, abruptly closed on Friday as construction begins on a new apartment community. articles.title: Domino’s CEO rips fast-food rivals’ value meals: ‘Not valuable’

articles.summary: Domino's Pizza CEO, Russell Weiner, has criticized fast food rivals for offering value meals in an attempt to lure customers back to their restaurants due to high inflation. He stated that value meals such as those offered by McDonald's were not all they were advertised to be. McDonald's recently introduced a $5 value meal, offering a McDouble or McChicken sandwich with small fries, four pieces of Chicken McNuggets and a small soft drink. Burger King and Taco Bell have also offered similar temporary value deals. Despite these criticisms, Weiner remains positive about Domino's revamped loyalty program and new products like the New York-style pizza have boosted sales. Last week, Domino’s saw its stock price drop by 14%, marking its worst one-day drop in over a decade.

articles.title: US crude oil prices retreat amid doubts about further stock draw
articles.description: U.S. crude oil inventories have depleted faster than normal over the last four weeks – squeezing hedge funds running short positions, keeping spot prices firm and the futures curve in a steep backwardation.
articles.content: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) - U.S. crude oil inventories have depleted faster than normal over the last four weeks – squeezing hedge funds running short positions, keeping spot prices firm and the futur... [5185 symbols]
articles.summary: U.S. crude oil inventories have depleted faster than normal over the last four weeks, leading to a sharp drop in hedge funds' short positions. This support kept spot prices firm and the futures curve in a steep backwardation. Commercial crude inventories across the United States depleted by 24 million barrels between June 21 and July 19, according to the Energy Information Administration (EIA). This is more than twice as fast as the average over the previous ten years. Most of the stocks were taken from refineries and tank farms along the Gulf of Mexico and around the delivery point for the NYMEX WTI futures contract at Cushing in Oklahoma. Despite this, both spot prices and calendar spreads have retreated in recent trading sessions. The EIA also noted that the drawdown more than halved the seasonal surplus on the Gulf Coast to 11 million barrels from 25 million barrels.

articles.summary: Online colleges in Michigan are a popular destination for students seeking a four-year degree, with many benefits such as convenience, flexibility, and affordability. The state offers numerous public and private schools where students can earn a degree online, whether they live in Michigan or not. These schools offer different degrees at different price points and offer different types of programs. We scored 38 accredited, nonprofit colleges offering online bachelor’s degree programs in Michigan using 18 data points in categories such as credibility, affordability, student outcomes, student experience, and application process. The schools were ranked based on their graduation rate within eight years of normal time and graduation rate of 93% or higher. All of the schools on our final list offer at least five fully online bachelor's degrees.

Nurses at Brigham and Women’s Hospital voted yesterday to authorize a one-da... [2294 symbols]
articles.summary: Nurses at Brigham and Women’s Hospital have voted to authorize a one-day strike, which their union claims is an effort to negotiate a more fair contract. The roughly 4,000 nurses at the Brigham are represented by the Massachusetts Nurses Association (MNA). The union claims that nurses are experiencing unsafe working conditions due to understaffing and that it is negatively affecting patient care. The vote was approved by 2,507 nurses, with 16 voting against the strike. The hospital has been negotiating with the union for nearly a year and plans to schedule a strike if necessary based on progress in negotiations.

articles.title: Council Post: Higher Education Institutions Must Adapt To Support Learners
articles.description: To truly fulfill its mission of empowering learners, institutions must dismantle barriers, making the path to education more equitable, affordable and accessible.
articles.content:
Elise Awwad is president and CEO of DeVry University.

Discussions about the value of higher education are increasingly becoming kitchen table conversations, with current and prospective students expr... [6841 symbols]
articles.summary: Elise Awwad, president and CEO of DeVry University, has highlighted the need for higher education institutions to adapt to the increasing cost of college education. She argues that institutions must make the path to education more equitable, affordable and accessible. She suggests that colleges and universities can help by ensuring their pricing structures are transparent and straightforward, breaking down tuition and fees so students understand what each charge covers and how it supports their education. These efforts can significantly enhance student outcomes and enhance student retention and graduation rates. Despite a decline in college enrollment, 94% of adults believe at least one type of postsecondary credential is valuable. Awwads urges colleges and university leaders to prioritize affordability and financial support for students, prioritizing student retention, and increasing non-repayable financial aid to reduce dependence on loans. She also suggests that transparent communication and support services can improve student outcomes.

articles.summary: Angola's new Cabinda crude oil refinery is on track to start up later this year before ramping up to full first phase production of 30,000 barrels a day by July next year, according to the plant's Chief Executive Marcelo Hofke. The modular refinery, which will produce naphtha, jet fuel, diesel and heavy fuel oil, is expected to produce 10% of Angola’s domestic fuel market before doubling this market share once the second phase is completed. The first phase's cost will reach $473 million, with engineering for phase 2 starting soon after the commissioning begins. The cost of the first phase is estimated at $1 billion.

The award-winning wire-free and radiation-free technology for localizing lesions for breast cancer surgery improves the patient experience and has earned praise from surgeons for its accuracy and ease of use.
articles.content: CHARLESTON, S.C. and DEERFIELD, Ill., July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- MUSC Hollings Cancer Center, an NCI-designated cancer center within the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), the state's onl... [4853 symbols]

keywords.name: MOLLI Surgicals Advanced Breast Cancer Technology

entities.data: The Medical University of South Carolina

articles.summary: The Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), the state's only comprehensive academic health system, has become the first in South Carolina to adopt the MOLLI® 2 System, a wireless and radiation-free technology for localizing lesions for breast cancer surgery. The system is praised by surgeons for its accuracy and ease of use, and is easy to use, reliable, and precise, improving efficiency and enhancing the patient experience. The MOLLi 2 System allows radiologists to mark lesions with a localization device, a device that can be placed up to 30 days before surgery without the need to synchronize schedules with surgery. This technology allows surgeons to direct surgeons to the lesion with millimeter precision and eliminates the need for wire-guided localization.

articles.summary: Leishla Maldonado and Osman Cortave, co-owners of LOMA in Providence's Federal Hill neighborhood, will open their new bar in August. They were born in Guatemala and moved to East Boston as children, where they grew up undocumented. The bar will only hold 25 people and will be filled with Latin jazz and salsa from the 1960s, inspired by records the brothers inherited from their grandfather. The space is designed to be more affordable for those with less access to high-end restaurants and bars. The main feature will be the Forraje, a julep-like drink with nutty, umami-forward flavors. The non-alcoholic program is being built with just as much alcohol as possible as the alcohol program.

articles.summary: Over 1,200 Denver landlords are still out of compliance with a city ordinance requiring them to obtain a residential rental license. The license requires landlords to pass a third-party inspection to ensure rental units are safe and up to code. The change went into effect last year for multi-unit properties and January 1 for single-unit family homes. Nearly 23,000 licenses have been issued, but 14 landlords have received a $999 fine without following up with a license resulting in about $80,000 in fines.

articles.title: India will not sign global tax deal until its concerns are addressed, official says
articles.description: India will not sign a global corporate tax deal focused on highly profitable multinational firms unless its concerns on dispute resolution and the treatment of withholding tax are addressed, a finance ministry official said on Thursday.  The so-called "Pillar 1" arrangement, part of a 2021 global two-part tax deal, aims to replace unilateral digital services taxes (DSTs) via a new mechanism to share taxing rights on multinational companies, such as U.S. tech giants Alphabet's Google and Amazon and Apple.  India is "constructively engaging" with all the countries  for the successful conclusion of "Pillar 1", and was hopeful the deal would be finalised soon, Revenue Secretary Sanjay Malhotra, one of the top finance ministry officials, said.
articles.content: NEW DELHI (Reuters) - India will not sign a global corporate tax deal focused on highly profitable multinational firms unless its concerns on dispute resolution and the treatment of withholding tax ar... [2100 symbols]
articles.summary: India will not sign a global corporate tax deal focused on highly profitable multinational firms unless concerns regarding dispute resolution and the treatment of withholding tax are addressed, according to a finance ministry official. The "Pillar 1" arrangement aims to replace unilateral digital services taxes (DSTs) with a new mechanism to share taxing rights on multinational companies such as Google and Amazon.com. As a conciliatory measure, India proposed to remove a 2% equalisation duty on digital service providers, which would cost the Indian government about 25 billion rupees ($300 million) annually. Negotiations are ongoing well past a June 30 deadline and governments are now looking to a Group of 20 finance leaders' meeting in Brazil for progress.

RENO, Nev., July 25, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- ITS Logistics today re... [3976 symbols]

keywords.name: ITS Logistics July Port Rail Ramp Index

articles.summary: IT Logistics has released the July forecast for the ITS Logistics US Port/Rail Ramp Freight Index, which reveals that pre-Peak Season shipping activity has increased volume increases but stressed import volumes at origin due to a lack of equipment. This has led to shippers having to book into new North American entry points outside of their current supply chain network due to overseas import origin equipment shortages. Despite these issues, North American inland transportation is not experiencing significant operational challenges. The Port of L.A. container volumes increased by 14.4% this month due to strong trade activity, threats of a labor strike at both the East and Gulf Coast ports, and consistent consumer spending. The International Longshoremen’s Association (ILA) current contract negotiations are stalled as there are only 70 days left in the current contract. The company also noted that there is not a high probability of a prolonged strike on the US East/Gulf Coast and Canada, but the threat of a strike is causing shippers to move their booking pairings back to the West Coast to avoid both regions. The index forecasts port container and dray operations for the Pacific, Atlantic, and Gulf regions.

articles.title: Can you use home equity to buy a duplex?
articles.description: Before using your home's equity to purchase a duplex, it's critical to weigh the pros against the cons.
articles.content:
We may receive commissions from some links to products on this page. Promotions are subject to availability and retailer terms.

The average homeowner in the U.S. currently has close to $300,000 in ho... [4925 symbols]
articles.summary: The average homeowner in the U.S. currently has close to $300,000 in home equity, and borrowing against home equity is cheaper than many other options, including credit cards. Two popular ways consumers can access their home equity are to take out a home equity loan or home equity line of credit (HELOC). These funds can be used for legal purposes, such as home renovations and repairs, but may not be taxed if used for other purposes like buying a second home. Tyler Meyer, CFP and CEO of RetireToAbundance.com, suggests that using home equity to purchase a duplex could be beneficial if the rental income covers the loan payments and offers additional cash flow. Katie Lindquist, certified financial planner and founder of Lindenwood Financial, suggests using your home equity for an investment property could be appropriate as a short-term financing solution. However, there are potential drawbacks to consider, including carrying significant debt, lacking an emergency fund or uncertain rental market.

articles.summary: Consumer behavior has evolved significantly since the pandemic of the era of the Black Plague, with consumers and retailers expecting faster, more convenient deliveries. The CEO of FarEye, Kushal Nahata, discusses the key trends in last-mile delivery, "The Year of Change: Eye on the Last Mile 2.0", which includes a report by DHL that can improve delivery efficiency by up to 20%. He also notes a shift in how last-minute delivery players measure their success rate from customer satisfaction to performance-based metrics. The report also highlights regional variations in the demand for speedier deliveries, with the APAC and Americas showing a significant appetite for same-day and next-day deliveries. Data-driven decision-making is still a crucial part of modern logistics strategies, with data-driven decisions still crucial.

articles.title: Jacksonville could demolish a Main Street bridge off-ramp to clear space for condo tower
articles.description: The former Jacksonville Landing parking lot beside Main Street bridge is where a developer wants to build a 320-unit condominium tower.
articles.content:
Demolishing a Main Street bridge off-ramp is back on the table after a developer proposed building a downtown condominium tower that's designed to be the tallest building between Atlanta and Miami.

T... [7104 symbols]
articles.summary: The city of Jacksonville may demolish a Main Street bridge off-ramp to create space for a downtown condominium tower. The developer, Cross Regions Group, has proposed the tallest building between Atlanta and Miami on the site. The ramp, which used to be the old Jacksonville Landing parking lot, would provide sweeping views of the St. Johns River and downtown skyline. The project would have 320 condo units and 35,000 square feet of restaurant and retail space. While the removal of the ramp would create more developable space, there are also challenges including a large JEA sewer pipe that makes a strip along the riverfront a no-build zone. The state Department of Transportation, which owns the bridge, has previously said it would allow demolition of the offramp, with an estimate in 2020 estimated at $3.2 million.

articles.summary: New York Community Bancorp subsidiary, Flagstar Bank, is selling its residential mortgage servicing business to Mr. Cooper Group Inc. for about $1.4 billion. articles.title: Supreme Court to hear cases of traders jailed over rate-rigging
articles.description: Tom Hayes and Carlo Palombo have secured permission to take bids to clear their names to the UK’s highest court.
articles.content:
Two former financial market traders jailed over interest rate benchmark manipulation will take bids to clear their names to the UK’s highest court.

Tom Hayes, 44, a former Citigroup and UBS trader, w... [3088 symbols]
articles.summary: Former financial market traders Tom Hayes and Carlo Palombo, two former traders convicted of multiple counts of conspiracy to defraud over manipulating the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate (Libor) between 2006 and 2010, will be taking their appeals to the UK's highest court, the Supreme Court, in an attempt to clear their names. Hayes, a former Citigroup and UBS trader, spent five and a half years in prison and is set to be released in 2021. Palombo was found guilty of conspiring with others to submit false or misleading Euro Interbank Offered Rates submissions between 2005 and 2009. The case was referred to the Court of Appeal by the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC), which investigates potential miscarriages of justice. Both men’s lawyers claim the UK was the only country where their conduct was considered a crime.

articles.title: What’s Up With CEO “Imposter Syndrome”? Here's The Truth
articles.description: This feeling is not a bug, but rather a feature of what people stepping into the CEO role feel. It’s actually a good thing.
articles.content: I recently came across an interview with Mark Arian, CEO of Korn Ferry Consulting, the organizational development arm of the global search firm. According to Arian, 71 percent of U.S. CEOs say they ex... [6011 symbols]
articles.summary: Mark Arian, CEO of Korn Ferry Consulting, has revealed that 71 percent of U.S. CEOs experience "imposter syndrome," a crisis of confidence, according to a recent survey by Korn ferry. The survey also found that employees across all titles and compensation levels are struggling with feelings of doubt at work. Senior management, including CEOs (71%) and other senior executives, are more likely than early-stage professionals (33%) to exhibit signs of imposter syndrome. However, 85 percent of CEOs expressed their belief in their ability to perform the job functions. Arian argues that this is not a bug but a feature of what CEOs stepping into the CEO role feel. He also warns against labeling these CEOs as "imperformed", stating that their job is to anticipate a world that does not exist and anticipate future challenges.

Sean Harvey, who owns several of the vehicles, estimated that in total, 14 coaches had been damaged and estimated the cost to repair his vehicles would be around £20,000.

articles.title: Adobe exec compared Creative Cloud cancellation fees to ‘heroin’
articles.description: General counsel Dana Rao says newly-unredacted copy of the FTC’s complaint against Adobe for hidden fees and complicated cancellation flows isn’t all that it’s made out to be.
articles.content: Early termination fees are “a bit like heroin for Adobe,” according to an Adobe executive quoted in the FTC’s newly unredacted complaint against the company for allegedly hiding fees and making it too... [5467 symbols]

entities.data: the Restore Online Shoppers’ Confidence Act

articles.summary: Adobe has been sued by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) for allegedly hiding fees and making it too difficult to cancel Creative Cloud. The FTC alleges that Adobe failed to clearly disclose the early termination fee for annual Creative Cloud plans billed monthly, which are not disclosed anywhere on the order screen. The complaint also alleges that the company lacks a simple process for canceling a Creative Cloud subscription. Adobe CEO, Raja Rao, responded to the FTC's claim that Adobe had already begun an overhaul of its subscription practices in October 2021. The court's case hinges on the Restore Confidence Act, which requires online retailers to conspicuously disclose all material terms of stores, as well as provide clear billing information.

articles.title: Water privatization is on the rise in Pennsylvania. Here’s what you need to know
articles.description: A panel of experts discussed Pa.’s private water industry, how it’s regulated, and options for when service is subpar.
articles.content:
Water privatization is on the rise in Pennsylvania. Here’s what you need to know

This story was produced by the State College regional bureau of Spotlight PA, an independent, nonpartisan newsroom ded... [7843 symbols]

entities.data: the State College Borough Water Authority
the National Association of Water Companies

articles.summary: The number of systems acquired by for-profit companies in Pennsylvania has increased in recent years, with over 150 water utilities across the state now under the jurisdiction of the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. However, there are also downsides to water privatization, which includes financial resources and staffing, but also limits local authority when communities have issues with their service. The investigation by Spotlight PA found that the Rock Spring Water Company, a private company in rural Centre County, has failed its customers, nearly 500 customers, leading to years of neglect leading to a crumbling infrastructure. The state Department of Environmental Protection monitors drinking water safety for drinking water. Customers can file a complaint about billing issues or rate protests with the commission, but are encouraged to speak up. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission oversees private water providers statewide and monitors rate increase requests and other service issues.

articles.summary: Ian Wilding, CEO of Hangar 75, has written a Council Post about the importance of well-being-driven strategies in business. These strategies can provide profound benefits to all stakeholders, including customers, employees, suppliers, and investors alike. Well-being encompasses physical, mental and emotional health, and brands that focus on these can foster stronger loyalty, increased engagement, and sustained growth. Companies like Apple and Google have been praised for their focus on user well-Being through features like Screen Time, which helps users monitor and control their device usage. Investors are also looking for ethical and sustainable investment opportunities. Companies that prioritize well-be-being often see a positive impact on their financial performance, making them attractive to investors.

articles.title: NHS spending rules risk depriving Britain of new medicine, warns AstraZeneca boss
articles.description: Sir Pascal Soriot criticises spending watchdog’s decision to block life-extending breast cancer drug
articles.content: However, the drug is not available for NHS patients in England and Wales because of the Nice decision. Campaigners have claimed that for thousands of women this has cut their lives short. The treatmen... [2756 symbols]
articles.summary: AristZeneca CEO, Sir Pascal, has warned that the UK's NHS spending rules could deprive Britain of new medicine, potentially depriving thousands of women of life. The company's breast cancer drug, which is available in other countries including Scotland, the United States and Romania, was blocked by Nice in March after it deemed it a "moderately severe disease" that did not offer value for money. Sir Pascal argued that the current system was creating a "roadblock" which could affect other drugs for cancer and other severe diseases, and that it could lead to drug makers to invest less in Britain. He also called on the Prime Minister to review the decision-making process. This comes after AstraZeneca previously criticised the UK’s “discouraging” taxes and snubbed Britain for a new $400m new drug factory in 2023, citing the less attractive investment environment.

articles.title: Why some Phoenix offices sit empty and others can't keep up with demand
articles.description: 24% of office space sits vacant, and yet Phoenix can't meet the high-end building demand.
articles.content: There's a tale of two office markets unfolding in the Valley: Nearly a quarter of our office space sits vacant, and yet we don't have enough high-end buildings to meet employer demand. The big picture... [2254 symbols]

keywords.name: CBRE vice president Charlie von Arentschildt

articles.summary: The office market in Phoenix has seen a disparity in which nearly a quarter of the city's office space is vacant and yet not enough high-end buildings are available to meet employer demand. Despite this, businesses are returning to in-person work, often seeking luxury headquarter-like buildings with amenities that make leaving the house worthwhile. CBRE vice president Charlie von Arentschildt said that Phoenix is not building enough of this type of "trophy" office space. He predicts that the Valley will see at least one quarter where there is no active construction of high-value offices next year, a feat that has never happened in the modern era. Developers are delaying construction due to uncertainty about leasing the buildings at the high prices they would have to charge. The middle-of-the-road inventory of older buildings is also contributing to the overall office vacancy rate, which is driving up the overall vacancy rate. Nationwide office vacancy rates reached a record 20.1% in the second quarter, the highest since at least 1979.

articles.summary: The article suggests that the role, remit, and goal of Revenue Operations should be defined, funding, and accelerating the growth of these roles. The author has conducted over fifty interviews with CROs and Revenue Operations leaders and reviewed over 100 academic and commercial research studies on commercial transformation. Most struggled to manage the complexity of the modern commercial model and were challenged by the complexities of fostering teamwork across marketing, sales, product, finance and analytics functions. The financial understanding of this transformation is also a crucial issue, as many companies lack a financial basis for calculating and measuring RevOps.

articles.title: Small stocks are about to take over? Wall Street has heard that before.
articles.description: After getting trounced by their larger rivals for years, some of the smallest stocks on...
articles.content: Trader Gregory Rowe works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, July 22, 2024. After getting trounced by their larger rivals for years, some of the smallest stocks on Wall Street have s... [3076 symbols]
articles.summary: After years of losing to larger Wall Street giants, some of the smallest stocks have seen significant growth. Hopes for cuts to interest rates have led investors to view smaller stocks differently, as they often carry heavy debt burdens and lower borrowing costs than large multinationals. The Russell 2000 index saw an 11.5% surge over five days, compared to the 1.6% gain for the big stocks in the S&P 500. Investors invested $9.9 billion into funds focused on small U.S. stocks last week, the largest amount since 2007, according to Deutsche Bank. This is seen as encouraging signals for analysts who believe a market with many stocks rising is healthier than one dependent on a handful of stars. However, small stocks are also more dependent on consumers' spending, and may not benefit from the rise of a Republican sweep in November's elections due to President Joe Biden's disastrous debate performance.

articles.title: Prisoners fight against working in heat on former slave plantation, raising hope for change in South
articles.description: As daily temperatures hit record highs across much of the South, a federal judge has taken...
articles.content: In this Aug. 18, 2011 photo, prison guards ride horses that were broken by inmates as they return from farm work detail at the Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola, La. In September, several incarce... [5210 symbols]
articles.summary: As temperatures hit record highs across much of the South, a federal judge has taken an unusual step, challenging the treatment of mostly Black incarcerated workers in the fields. In September, several incarcerated workers along with the New Orleans-based advocacy group Voice of the Experienced filed a class-action lawsuit calling for an end to the farm line and accusing the state of cruel and unusual punishment. The lawsuit was dismissed by Louisiana's corrections department, but the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals sided with the judge. Prison officials have already taken steps to improve conditions, providing inmates with sunscreen and pop-up tents for shade, and providing five-minute breaks every half hour when heat alerts are issued. The Obama administration is proposing heat index restrictions for millions of agricultural workers and others who work outside.

articles.title: Southwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its history
articles.description: Southwest said it expects about a third of the seats on its Boeing 737s will offer “extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.”
articles.content: Southwest Airlines is ending open seating and will offer extra legroom seats on its airplanes as mounting pressure on the carrier to increase revenue prompts the biggest changes to its business model ... [2852 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is ending open seating and offering extra legroom seats on its airplanes, marking the largest change in its history in 53 years. The airline plans to start selling the first flights offering additional legroom next year and will also begin overnight flights starting in February. The change comes amid increased pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management to segment its product like other airlines after he disclosed a nearly $2 billion stake in Southwest. Southwest's CEO Bob Jordan argued that the change was the right time for the airline and that 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat. However, no changes were made to its two free checked bags policy.

articles.title: Major funders bet big on rural America and ‘everyday democracy’
articles.description: The Trust for Civic Life — a collaborative of 15 grantmakers, mostly high-profile national funders — sees small, local groups as instruments of change — modern versions of the organizations that scholars from Alexis de Tocqueville to Robert Putnam have...
articles.content:
Someone may need to tell Carlton Turner that he’s working to save democracy.

Turner is co-director of the Mississippi Center for Cultural Production in the town of Utica, population 600, where his fa... [8136 symbols]

entities.data: the Mississippi Center for Cultural Production
the Community Foundation of Greater Dubuque

articles.summary: The Trust for Civic Life, a new philanthropic venture, has announced $8 million in funding for 20 inaugural grantees in an effort to revitalize rural, often high-poverty towns, regions, and tribal areas. The Trust sees small, local groups as modern versions of organizations that have been praised for their contributions to American democracy. Grantees exemplify what the trust calls “everyday democracy” as they bring people together to address often-fundamental concerns such as a fading industry, a dilapidated park, or access to quality health care. The trust partners include high-profile national funders such as the Ford Foundation and Rockefeller Brothers Fund. It's a rare investment by national philanthropy in rural America.
